key_facts: LinkedIn Series B pitch presented three business ideas with no revenue at the time
The three business ideas were not the source of LinkedIn's majority revenue
Individual subscription was initially believed to be the primary revenue model
Corporate product inquiries began two weeks after launching the subscription model
A paper mock-up of the corporate product was created despite not being actively developed
A salesperson was hired to test market interest in the corporate product
Twenty out of thirty potential customers expressed interest in purchasing the corporate product
The company pivoted to focus on building the corporate product as its main revenue driver
The corporate product became the majority of LinkedIn's revenue and remains so today
key_opinions: Presenting three options during the pitch indicated uncertainty about the correct path
The shift from individual subscriptions to corporate products was a strategic pivot driven by customer demand
The early success of the corporate product was unexpected given initial planning timelines
The corporate product's adoption was faster than anticipated, accelerating development priorities
Customer interest in the corporate product validated the pivot decision
